study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine how gut microbiota composition influences iron-promoted tumorigenesis in colorectal cancer (CRC) and whether microbiota-targeted interventions could mitigate these effects.
results_summary: Iron supplementation promoted CRC and altered gut microbiota in mice receiving fecal microbiota transplantation (FMT) from CRC patients, but not from healthy controls or mice. Specific bacterial strains (Faecalibaculum rodentium, Holdemanella biformis, Bifidobacterium pseudolongum, and Alistipes inops) protected against iron-promoted tumorigenesis in FMT-CRC mice.
population_specificity: ApcMin/+ mice (a model for CRC) receiving FMT from healthy controls, CRC patients, or other mice.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the role of iron overload-related genes in wound healing and identify potential therapeutic targets.
results_summary: The study identified three hub genes (HIF1A, CDKN2A, EGFR) linked to iron overload in wound healing, with diagnostic value, and found that EGFR promotes skin wound healing. Potential drugs for treatment were also identified.
population_specificity: Not specified (study focused on gene expression and cell experiments).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the relationship between salivary iron levels and oral Candida colonization in OLP patients undergoing topical steroid therapy, comparing those with and without a history of oral candidiasis.
results_summary: The study found significantly higher salivary iron levels and Candida colony counts in OLP patients with a history of oral candidiasis compared to those without and healthy individuals, suggesting a link between elevated iron and Candida colonization.
population_specificity: 68 OLP patients (34 with a history of oral candidiasis, 34 without) and 34 healthy individuals.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine how varying iron oxide-loaded powdered activated carbon (FONP-PAC) ratios affect aerobic granular sludge (AGS) systems, focusing on granulation rates and pollutant removal efficiency.
results_summary: Higher iron oxide loading (S2) significantly improved sludge growth (87.14% larger than control) and pollutant removal (95.96% COD, 100% NH4+-N, 79.53% TN), while enhancing aerobic denitrification rates (71.68% above control). Microbial analysis showed enriched Bacteroidota and sustained Zoogloea abundance, indicating improved interspecies electron transfer and nitrogen removal.
population_specificity: Aerobic granular sludge (AGS) systems for wastewater treatment.
effective_dosage: Fe/C ratios (FC1 in S1, FC2 in S2) – specific amounts not detailed.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the prevalence and management of iron deficiency (ID) and anaemia in patients undergoing gynaecological surgery, focusing on preoperative screening and treatment.
results_summary: The study found high preoperative ID (70%-78%) and anaemia (28%-59%) rates among gynaecological surgery patients, with low screening (5%-33%) and treatment rates (12.5%-24% preoperatively, 25% postoperatively). It highlighted the need for better perioperative ID and anaemia management.
population_specificity: Patients undergoing gynaecological surgery, particularly those with conditions like uterine fibroids and gynaecological malignancies.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate sex-specific differences in brain iron metabolism and microglial iron storage capacity in Alzheimer's disease and small vessel disease patients.
results_summary: The study found a positive correlation between iron deposits and ferritin light chain levels in microglia in men with Alzheimer's disease, but a negative correlation in women. No such correlation was observed in small vessel disease patients of either sex.
population_specificity: Postmortem brain samples from Alzheimer's disease and small vessel disease patients of both sexes.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether education based on the theory of planned behavior (TPB) could effectively prevent iron deficiency anemia (IDA) in female high school students.
results_summary: The study found that the TPB-based educational intervention significantly improved attitudes, subjective norms, perceived behavioral control, behavioral intention, and behavior related to preventing IDA in the experimental group compared to the control group. The results suggest that such educational programs can effectively influence nutritional behaviors to prevent IDA.
population_specificity: Female high school students aged 14-19 years in Shiraz, Iran.
effective_dosage: Not specified (educational intervention involved six 50-60 minute sessions).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the effectiveness of combining Clostridium sulfidigenes HY-1 with iron-based nanoparticles (nFe0) for immobilizing Cd2+ and Pb2+ in mine wastewater and soil.
results_summary: The combination of C. sulfidigenes HY-1 with nFe0 showed synergistic effects, achieving immobilization rates of 89.3% for Cd2+ and 97.8% for Pb2+ in 5 days. The products of immobilization were identified as CdS, PbS, and FeS, demonstrating significant remediation effects in contaminated environments.
population_specificity: Mine wastewater and soil contaminated with Cd2+ and Pb2+.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare the therapeutic response and tolerability of intravenous iron sucrose and ferric carboxymaltose (FCM) in pregnant women with iron-deficiency anemia (IDA).
results_summary: Both iron sucrose and FCM significantly increased hemoglobin and serum ferritin levels, with FCM showing a greater improvement. Adverse events were minor and comparable between groups, with no serious adverse effects reported.
population_specificity: 334 pregnant women in the second or third trimester with moderate to severe IDA.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether iron starvation could enhance cuproptosis-like bacterial cell death, particularly in combating drug-resistant bacteria.
results_summary: The study found that iron starvation significantly aggravated proteotoxic stress and redox imbalance induced by Cu overload, leading to enhanced bacterial cell death at extremely low-dose Cu ions. The strategy was effective in a methicillin-resistant Staphylococcus aureus (MRSA)-infected diabetic mouse wound model.
population_specificity: MRSA-infected diabetic mice

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine the association between maternal anaemia (often linked to iron deficiency) and the risk of intrauterine growth restriction (IUGR) in pregnant women.
results_summary: The study found that maternal anaemia is associated with a significantly increased risk of IUGR (OR = 1.30), with severe anaemia showing a higher, though non-significant, risk (OR = 1.42). Subgroup analyses for mild and moderate anaemia did not show significant associations with IUGR.
population_specificity: Pregnant women (3,871,849 anaemic and 27,978,450 non-anaemic).

study_goal: The researchers sought to determine the cost-effectiveness of screening versus no screening for iron deficiency in women of reproductive age in the United States.
results_summary: Screening at a ferritin threshold of 25 μg/L was found to be the most cost-effective intervention, with an ICER of $680/QALY. The study also confirmed its cost-effectiveness in scenarios involving intravenous iron repletion.
population_specificity: Women of reproductive age in the United States.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to provide guidelines for detecting iron overload and initiating iron chelation therapy in thalassemia patients to improve long-term survival and quality of life.
results_summary: The study highlights the necessity of standardized iron chelation therapy to manage iron overload complications in thalassemia, including heart failure, liver cirrhosis, and developmental delays, and provides treatment strategies for different patient groups.
population_specificity: Patients with thalassemia (both transfusion-dependent and non-transfusion-dependent).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine the roles of iron-cycling bacteria and electroactive bacteria in nitrogen removal in constructed wetlands with iron-carbon substrates under different filling modes.
results_summary: The study found that constructed wetlands with separately filled iron-biochar substrates achieved higher total nitrogen removal (81%) and lower greenhouse gas emissions compared to mixed filling modes. Iron-cycling bacteria and electroactive bacteria, rather than nitrogen-transforming bacteria, were decisive in nitrogen removal.
population_specificity: Constructed wetlands treating low C/N ratio wastewater

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the efficacy and safety of intravenous iron in improving anemia and reducing transfusion requirements in cancer patients, particularly those receiving supportive care alone.
results_summary: IV iron significantly increased hemoglobin levels (from 7.6 g/dL to 9.3 g/dL by day 60) and reduced transfusion requirements by 55% overall (62% in supportive care patients), with minimal adverse reactions (1.1%).
population_specificity: Cancer patients receiving palliative care, including those on supportive care alone, at an integrated oncology center in Hong Kong.
study_duration: Follow-up periods included days 28 and 60, with transfusion data assessed up to 12 weeks.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine how iron (Fe) reduction influences soil organic carbon (SOC) decomposition under anoxic conditions and its implications for carbon loss in soils.
results_summary: The study found that iron reduction drives fast anoxic decomposition of SOC, accounting for up to 90% of anoxic CO2 production, and leads to the loss of Fe-bound OC, particularly in soils rich in reducible Fe and SOC.
population_specificity: 20 soils collected across a 24° latitude gradient in China

study_goal: The researchers aimed to review the applications, operational principles, and challenges of iron-oxide nanoparticles (IONPs) in biomedicine, particularly in MRI, drug delivery, and hyperthermia.
results_summary: The study found that IONPs show promising results in diagnosis, drug delivery, and treatment, with precision and efficacy in targeting therapeutic agents. However, challenges like biocompatibility, agglomeration, and toxicity were noted, along with strategies to address them.
population_specificity: Not specified (general biomedical applications)

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine the molecular function of BAR11, a ferritin-like protein, and its role in enhancing plant immunity by disrupting iron homeostasis in apple cells.
results_summary: BAR11 sequestered labile ferrous iron (Fe2+) in apple cells, inducing a low iron-mimicry state that activated defense-related genes and enhanced resistance against Valsa mali infection. The transcription factor MdWRKY40 was identified as a key modulator of this immune response.
population_specificity: Apple (Malus domestica) plants infected with Valsa mali.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the role of iron overload in promoting resistance to cytarabine-induced apoptosis in TP53-wild-type and TP53-mutant AML cells.
results_summary: Iron overload suppressed the TP53/BCL2/BAX signaling pathway, reducing cytarabine-induced apoptosis in AML cells. TFR1 was identified as a key regulator of iron-mediated resistance in TP53 wild-type AML cells.
population_specificity: Acute myeloid leukemia (AML) cells, specifically TP53-wild-type and TP53-mutant variants.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare the effectiveness of iron amino acid chelated (AACI) preparation versus ferric ammonium citrate (FAC) in treating iron deficiency anemia in school-age children.
results_summary: The study found that both AACI and FAC improved iron status indices, with AACI showing greater improvements in hemoglobin, MCV, serum iron, and serum ferritin levels, though the difference between the two treatments was not statistically significant.
population_specificity: 160 children aged 5-13 years with iron deficiency anemia.
effective_dosage: Once daily at bedtime (specific dosage not provided).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare the efficacy and tolerability of alternate-day versus daily oral iron replacement in women with iron deficiency anemia.
results_summary: Alternate-day iron administration (120 mg elemental iron) resulted in significantly higher hemoglobin increments at Day-28 compared to daily administration (60 mg elemental iron), with fewer adverse effects (9% vs. 45%). The difference in hemoglobin levels at Day-56 was not statistically significant.
population_specificity: Women aged ≥18 years with iron deficiency anemia (hemoglobin 6-10 g/dL, serum ferritin <30 µg/L).
effective_dosage: 120 mg elemental iron (2 × 200 mg ferrous sulphate tablets) on alternate days vs. 60 mg elemental iron (single FeSO4 tablet) daily.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether adding sesame jaggery balls to routine oral iron syrup improves iron status in children with moderate iron deficiency anemia.
results_summary: The intervention group showed statistically significant greater increases in hemoglobin, serum ferritin, and body weight compared to the control group receiving only iron syrup. The results suggest that sesame jaggery balls enhance iron supplementation efficacy.
population_specificity: Indian children aged 6-11 years with moderate iron deficiency anemia.
effective_dosage: 3 mg/kg/day elemental iron syrup + one sesame jaggery ball (60g sesame seeds and 60g jaggery) daily.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine how different iron supplementation regimens (every other day, once daily, twice daily) affect hepcidin levels and hematological outcomes in women with iron deficiency anemia.
results_summary: Twice-daily iron supplementation showed the most significant improvements in hemoglobin, MCV, and ferritin levels by the 15th day and third month, respectively, but with increased gastrointestinal side effects. No significant differences in hepcidin levels were observed across groups at three months.
population_specificity: 87 female participants aged 18-45 years with hemoglobin < 10 g/dL and serum ferritin < 20 ng/ml.
effective_dosage: Every other day, once daily, or twice daily iron therapy (specific iron compound and dosage not specified).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to examine the association between periodontitis and iron metabolism disorders and analyze characteristic changes in iron metabolism in periodontitis patients.
results_summary: Periodontitis patients showed higher systemic inflammation markers, increased serum hepcidin and ferritin, and decreased serum iron and transferrin. Non-surgical periodontal therapy improved these iron metabolism parameters after 3 months.
population_specificity: 79 Stage III/IV periodontitis patients and 79 healthy controls.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the effectiveness of conservative iron chelation in treating neurodegeneration with brain iron accumulation, specifically in neuroferritinopathy and parkinsonism-dystonia related to VAC14 gene mutations.
results_summary: The study reported clinical stability after 2 years of conservative iron chelation, with improvements in radiological images, suggesting potential benefits for managing these conditions.
population_specificity: Patients with neurodegeneration with brain iron accumulation, including neuroferritinopathy and parkinsonism-dystonia related to VAC14 gene mutations.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the effectiveness of a nano-zero-valent iron-loaded biochar-zeolite composite (nZVI-BCZo) for removing Cd(II) and As(III) from water.
results_summary: The study found that nZVI-BCZo had maximum adsorption capacities of 28.09 mg/g for Cd(II) and 186.99 mg/g for As(III) under optimal conditions, with higher affinity for As(III). The material retained good adsorption capacity after three regeneration cycles, indicating reusability.
population_specificity: Water treatment applications (not human or animal subjects).
effective_dosage: Not specified (batch adsorption experiments under controlled conditions).
study_duration: Adsorption time of 360 minutes per batch.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the effects of iron supplementation combined with light/dark cycles on the production of value-added substances and biomass during photofermentation of residual wine lees.
results_summary: Iron supplementation, combined with light/dark cycles, significantly enhanced the production of CoQ10, carotenoids, and bacteriochlorophylls, while maintaining 5-ALA and PHA levels. It also improved biomass production and organic matter removal.
population_specificity: Residual wine lees (microbial fermentation system)

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the drug release kinetics and cytotoxicity of AST-loaded SPIONLA/BSA nanoparticles for targeted cholangiocarcinoma therapy.
results_summary: The study found that AST-loaded SPIONLA/BSA exhibited pH-sensitive drug release, with release kinetics fitting the Korsmeyer-Peppas model, and demonstrated significant cytotoxicity against cholangiocarcinoma cells, particularly KKU-213, reducing viability by 54.73%.
population_specificity: In vitro cholangiocarcinoma cell lines (KKU-055 and KKU-213).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare the effects of intramuscular injection and oral supplementation of iron on growth performance, iron homeostasis, and redox status in suckling piglets.
results_summary: The combination of intramuscular injection and oral supplementation (FeDPO) resulted in the highest weaning weight, hemoglobin, and serum iron levels, along with improved redox status compared to other groups. Oral supplementation alone (FeOra) also showed benefits in red blood cell levels and antioxidant enzyme activities, while intramuscular injection alone (FeDex) had higher oxidative stress markers.
population_specificity: Suckling piglets (newborn to postnatal day 21).
effective_dosage: Intramuscular dextran-bound iron (200 mg Fe on postnatal day 3) and/or oral FerkoFer® (2.2 g Fe daily from postnatal day 2 to 13).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to explore the effect and mechanism of sulfate on the removal of 1,1,2-trichloroethane (1,1,2-TCA) using zero-valent iron (ZVI) coupled with biostimulation in groundwater.
results_summary: The coupled ZVI and biostimulation systems enhanced 1,1,2-TCA degradation by an order of magnitude under sulfate stress, but complete dechlorination of vinyl chloride (VC) remained challenging without obligate organohalide respiration bacteria. Sulfate dynamically altered ZVI sulfidation and microbial interactions, affecting dechlorination efficiency differently in micron and nano ZVI systems.
population_specificity: Groundwater contaminated with chlorinated hydrocarbons

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine the role of ferroptosis and COPB1 in iron accumulation-induced osteoporosis and explore COPB1 as a potential therapeutic target.
results_summary: Iron accumulation altered COPB1 expression, leading to reduced osteogenic ability and inducing ferroptosis and endoplasmic reticulum stress. COPB1 overexpression restored osteogenic function in cells and mice.
population_specificity: Osteoporosis populations and Hamp knockout (KO) iron accumulation mouse models.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the catalytic performance of a single iron atom impregnated on porous N-doped carbon (FeSAC/NC) for degrading tetracycline (TC) in wastewater via the Fenton reaction.
results_summary: FeSAC/NC achieved 92% TC removal in 40 minutes compared to 23% with PMS alone, primarily through a nonradical pathway involving singlet oxygen and electron transfer. The porous NC matrix also contributed to TC adsorption via pyrrolic and graphitic nitrogen sites.
population_specificity: Not applicable (in vitro study on wastewater treatment).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to assess the effectiveness and safety of ferric derisomaltose (FDI) as a high-dose IV iron treatment for iron deficiency in patients where oral iron was unsuitable or ineffective.
results_summary: The study found that FDI increased mean hemoglobin by 20.9 g/L and ferritin by 188.8 µg/L, with 65.1% of treatment courses resulting in a response (non-anemia or Hb increase ≥20 g/L). However, patients remained anemic after >65% of courses, indicating suboptimal dosing relative to iron need.
population_specificity: 2,468 patients with iron deficiency where oral iron was contraindicated, ineffective, or not tolerated.
effective_dosage: Mean dose of 1,244 mg per course (estimated need: 1,580 mg).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to explain the prevalence of iron deficiency in IBD patients, improve diagnostic tools, and recommend treatment strategies for iron deficiency in this population.
results_summary: Iron deficiency is common in IBD patients and impacts quality of life and disease progression. Intravenous iron is effective and well-tolerated but underused, and early treatment before anemia symptoms appear is recommended.
population_specificity: Patients with inflammatory bowel disease (IBD)

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the role of iron in Acinetobacter baumannii and evaluate the potential of iron chelators, particularly β-thujaplicin, as an alternative therapeutic approach to combat antibiotic resistance.
results_summary: Iron deprivation disrupted bacterial growth, destabilized membranes, and disintegrated biofilm matrices. β-thujaplicin demonstrated strong antibacterial efficacy and enhanced the effects of colistin and chloramphenicol when used at sub-MIC levels.
population_specificity: Acinetobacter baumannii (bacterial pathogen)
effective_dosage: Not specified (sub-MIC levels of β-thujaplicin used alongside colistin and chloramphenicol)

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the potential of iron chelators (deferoxamine and deferiprone) in stabilizing HIF-1α to counteract follicular degradation and promote hair regrowth in autoimmune-induced alopecia.
results_summary: Iron chelators demonstrated improvements in hair density, thickness, and elasticity, with a reduction in hair loss by up to 66.8% over six months, suggesting their therapeutic potential in autoimmune alopecia management.
population_specificity: Individuals with autoimmune-induced alopecia (e.g., alopecia areata).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the effects of iron-enriched Saccharomyces cerevisiae on growth performance, anemia, iron retention, and hepatic antioxidant characteristics in juvenile rainbow trout.
results_summary: The study found that iron-enriched S. cerevisiae increased hepatic iron concentration and improved plasma antioxidant capacity without negatively affecting growth or hepatic histology. However, dietary cottonseed meal alone reduced hematocrit and hemoglobin levels, which were mitigated by S. cerevisiae supplementation.
population_specificity: Juvenile rainbow trout (Oncorhynchus mykiss)

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the correlation between H. pylori infection and iron-deficiency anemia (IDA), its potential mechanisms, and the efficacy of H. pylori eradication therapy in IDA patients.
results_summary: The study found that H. pylori infection is correlated with IDA, and combining H. pylori eradication with iron supplementation is more effective in treating IDA than iron supplementation alone, particularly in unexplained or refractory cases.
population_specificity: Individuals with iron-deficiency anemia (IDA), particularly those with unexplained or refractory cases.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine the effects of chemical inhibition of NOXs and NLRP3 activity on colonic iron metabolism and inflammatory reactions in a murine model of DSS-induced ulcerative colitis.
results_summary: Chemical inhibition of NOXs and NLRP3 significantly reduced colonic iron overload and macrophage infiltration, alleviating inflammatory response and tissue damage. NOXs inhibition notably suppressed NLRP3 expression and oxidative damage, while NLRP3 inhibition did not affect NOXs expression or oxidative damage.
population_specificity: Murine model (mice) with DSS-induced ulcerative colitis.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the role of ferritinophagy and iron metabolism in canine osteosarcoma cells to identify potential new treatment targets.
results_summary: The study found that canine osteosarcoma cells overexpress ferritinophagy-related proteins (FTH1 and NCOA4) and proliferating cell nuclear antigen (PCNA), suggesting that these cells rely on iron mobilization to sustain proliferation. These findings indicate that targeting iron metabolism could be a viable therapeutic strategy for canine osteosarcoma.
population_specificity: Canine osteoblastic osteosarcoma (COOS) samples and normal canine bone samples.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether preoperative iron supplementation reduces the risk of blood transfusion in non-anemic patients undergoing major surgeries.
results_summary: Preoperative iron supplementation significantly reduced transfusion requirements (OR = 0.54) and increased hemoglobin levels on the first postoperative day, though the effect on hemoglobin levels throughout the first week was inconclusive.
population_specificity: Non-anemic patients (average age 71, 44% women) undergoing major surgeries, particularly cardiac procedures.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine the optimal time interval between ferumoxytol administration and brain MRI to minimize unintended imaging effects.
results_summary: The study found that 68% of patients exhibited enhancement or signal drop on T1 weighted images, and 63% showed susceptibility artifacts on SWI/GRE sequences after ferumoxytol treatment. A 5-6 day interval between administration and MRI was recommended to reduce these effects.
population_specificity: 40 patients who underwent MRI within 3 months of ferumoxytol treatment.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to develop an Fe/Co dual-catalyzed strategy for synthesizing alkenyl unnatural amino acids and peptide modifications, avoiding expensive photoredox catalysts and substrate preactivation while preserving chirality.
results_summary: The study demonstrated that the Fe/Co dual-catalyzed approach successfully synthesized alkenyl unnatural amino acids and modified peptides, enabling potential applications in boron-neutron capture therapy (BNCT) drug candidates. The method preserved amino acid chirality and avoided costly reagents.
population_specificity: Not specified (in vitro or chemical synthesis context)

study_goal: The researchers aimed to develop and validate a comprehensive detection method for assessing old goafs in iron mines, focusing on their distribution, depth, and stability.
results_summary: The study successfully applied a combined geophysical and drilling approach to map and model old goafs in the Dunqiu iron mine, identifying their dimensions, volumes, and stability risks. The method demonstrated practical utility in evaluating goaf collapse risks.
population_specificity: Old goafs in the Dunqiu iron mine, China.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether chloride enhances the activation of peroxymonosulfate by iron-biochar composites for efficient micropollutant degradation in water.
results_summary: The study found that the Fe/BC/PMS/Cl- system rapidly degraded bisphenol A (BPA) within 1.0 min, with Fe(IV) as the dominant reactive species. The system remained effective despite background anions or natural organic matter and was reusable for multiple treatment cycles.
population_specificity: Water sources containing micropollutants (e.g., bisphenol A).
effective_dosage: Not specified (tested at varying Cl- contents, PMS levels, Fe/BC doses, and pH).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the mechanism by which Tiliroside (TIL) induces ferroptosis in ovarian cancer cells, focusing on its interaction with AKR1B1 and modulation of iron metabolism.
results_summary: TIL demonstrated anti-tumor activity by inducing ferroptosis in ovarian cancer cells, evidenced by ROS, MDA, and Fe2+ accumulation and GPX4 reduction. It modulated iron metabolism via iron ion transport and ferritinophagy, and inhibited tumor growth in xenograft models without significant tissue damage.
population_specificity: Ovarian cancer cells (A2780 and OVCAR8) and xenograft model mice.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the effectiveness of sulfidated zero-valent iron (S-ZVI) bimetals in degrading chlorinated solvents, specifically trichloroethylene (TCE), in the vapor phase.
results_summary: Sulfidated materials with a 0.05 S/ZVI molar ratio achieved up to 99% degradation of TCE vapors within 18 hours, with first-order degradation constants of 5-5.7 d-1. Column tests demonstrated 70% degradation over 25 days, and modeling suggested an 18 cm reactive barrier could ensure 99% degradation.
population_specificity: Not applicable (environmental study, no human subjects).
study_duration: Up to 30 days for aging tests, 25 days for column tests.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to test the "early-rise late-decline" hypothesis regarding thalamic iron levels in multiple sclerosis (MS) patients, examining whether age differences in study cohorts explain conflicting findings.
results_summary: The study found lower thalamic susceptibility (indicating lower iron levels) in both younger and older MS patients compared to controls, contradicting the "early rise" hypothesis. Results were consistent across analyses, suggesting previous reports of increased iron may stem from demographic or clinical differences rather than QSM processing artifacts.
population_specificity: People with multiple sclerosis (pwMS), divided into younger (average age below 40) and older (average age above 40) cohorts.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether the combination of aminolevulinate and ferrous iron (ALA/Fe) could improve mitochondrial function and energy status in DARS2-deficient cells as a potential treatment for LBSL.
results_summary: ALA/Fe exposure rescued mitochondrial and antioxidant deficiencies in fibroblasts from LBSL-affected individuals, but these effects were blocked by dexamethasone, an Nrf-2 inhibitor. The study suggests ALA/Fe may activate Nrf-2-mediated cytoprotection, offering a potential treatment pathway for LBSL and other mitochondrial diseases.
population_specificity: Fibroblasts from two brothers with LBSL harboring specific DARS2 mutations.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the quantitative effect of alpha-lipoic acid (ALA) supplementation on iron metabolism parameters, including serum iron, total iron binding capacity, hemoglobin, and ferritin.
results_summary: The meta-analysis found no statistically significant effects of ALA on ferritin, serum iron, or total iron binding capacity. However, subgroup analysis showed a significant increase in hemoglobin in patients with hematological disorders and in studies lasting more than 8 weeks.
population_specificity: 529 participants from 10 studies, including patients with hematological disorders.
study_duration: Varied, with some studies lasting >8 weeks

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the efficacy of scrap iron filings (SIFs) in controlling hydrogen sulfide (H2S) emissions in septic tanks by influencing microbial activity and sulfide oxidation.
results_summary: The addition of SIFs reduced dissolved sulfides by 45.6% and gaseous H2S by 92.6%, while altering microbial communities by decreasing sulfate-reducing bacteria and increasing sulfur-oxidizing bacteria. SIFs also slightly improved effluent C/N and C/P ratios, potentially aiding nitrogen and phosphorus removal.
population_specificity: Laboratory-scale septic tank reactor (not human subjects).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the effectiveness of various treatments, including iron-related interventions, for renal anemia in chronic kidney disease patients.
results_summary: The study found that modulating iron metabolism, reducing hepcidin levels, and increasing EPO and HIF expressions can improve renal anemia. Clinical trials indicated that treatments like Roxadustat and Ferumoxytol showed positive effects.
population_specificity: Individuals with chronic kidney disease suffering from renal anemia.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to analyze factors contributing to blood donor deferrals, particularly focusing on low hemoglobin levels and their impact on donor retention.
results_summary: Low hemoglobin was the most common deferral reason (27.5% of deferred donors), disproportionately affecting female donors. The study suggested iron supplementation for female donors as a potential intervention to reduce deferrals.
population_specificity: Blood donors at King Fahad Hospital Al Hofuf, Saudi Arabia (21,149 donors, predominantly male, aged 21-30 years).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine the impact of iron deficiency on the functional outcome of acute ischemic stroke patients.
results_summary: Iron deficiency was strongly associated with poor functional outcome at 90 days in acute ischemic stroke patients, with an adjusted odds ratio of 2.328 (95% CI 1.272-4.263, p = 0.006). The study suggests iron supplementation could be a potential therapeutic strategy to improve outcomes.
population_specificity: Acute ischemic stroke patients admitted to stroke units of four comprehensive stroke centers (mean age 73 ± 13, 47.5% female).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the causes, screening recommendations, and treatment efficacy of iron deficiency anemia in children.
results_summary: The study found that iron deficiency is the most common cause of microcytic anemia in children, with ferrous sulfate (2-6 mg/kg per day) being the most effective oral iron supplementation. Delayed cord clamping may prevent early iron deficiency, but clinical outcomes are uncertain.
population_specificity: Children, particularly infants and those under 1 year of age.
effective_dosage: 2-6 mg/kg per day of ferrous sulfate.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the exposure-response relationships and pharmacokinetic/pharmacodynamic modeling of sotatercept for treating pulmonary arterial hypertension (PAH).
results_summary: The study found that increasing sotatercept concentration improved clinical endpoints like 6-minute walk distance (6MWD) and pulmonary vascular resistance (PVR), while also assessing safety via hemoglobin levels.
population_specificity: Patients with pulmonary arterial hypertension (PAH).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare the impact of intravenous versus oral iron supplementation on iron deficiency anemia in patients with rectal cancer undergoing preoperative chemoradiotherapy.
results_summary: The study is ongoing, so results are not yet available, but it is designed to evaluate hemoglobin normalization, changes in iron parameters, transfusion needs, and postoperative complications.
population_specificity: Patients with primary rectal cancer and confirmed iron-deficiency anemia who are candidates for preoperative chemoradiotherapy.
study_duration: From the start of treatment to the day of admission for surgery (duration not explicitly stated).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether oral phosphate supplementation could prevent hypophosphatemia induced by ferric carboxymaltose in patients with iron deficiency anemia or isolated iron deficiency undergoing major surgery.
results_summary: The study found that oral phosphate supplementation did not prevent hypophosphatemia but reduced its incidence. Phosphate co-administration did not interfere with the efficacy of ferric carboxymaltose in treating iron deficiency anemia.
population_specificity: Adult patients (mean age 56 ± 17 years, 57% female) scheduled for elective major abdominal or thoracic surgery with iron deficiency or iron deficiency anemia.
effective_dosage: Single preoperative intravenous dose of ferric carboxymaltose; oral phosphate (18 mmol daily) or placebo three times a day for 30 days.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the long-term effects of prenatal and postnatal iron and folic acid (IFA) supplementation, compared to other nutrient supplements, on autonomic nervous system regulation in children.
results_summary: The study found that prenatal micronutrient supplementation, including IFA, influenced sympathetic nervous system (SNS) reactivity, with children in the IFA group showing less PEP reactivity compared to other groups. A better home environment was associated with longer baseline PEP and more SNS reactivity, suggesting environmental and nutritional factors jointly affect ANS regulation.
population_specificity: Children born to women in Ghana who participated in a randomized controlled trial from 2009 to 2014.
effective_dosage: Daily supplementation during pregnancy until delivery, followed by placebo until 6 months postpartum (exact dosage not specified).
study_duration: From pregnancy until 6 months postpartum for mothers; infants in the SQ-LNS group received supplements from 6 to 18 months.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the efficacy of intravenous ferric carboxymaltose (FCM) in improving outcomes for heart failure patients with iron deficiency anemia, focusing on mortality, hospitalization rates, functional capacity, and quality of life.
results_summary: FCM significantly improved 6-minute walk distance and quality of life but did not significantly impact cardiovascular death, all-cause mortality, or hospitalization rates.
population_specificity: Heart failure patients with iron deficiency anemia.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate longitudinal changes in iron biomarkers during pregnancy and determine early pregnancy iron status cutoffs that predict third-trimester iron deficiency.
results_summary: The study found that iron deficiency prevalence increased significantly throughout pregnancy, with ferritin <60 μg/L at 15 weeks predicting deficiency later. Iron-containing supplements taken pre/early pregnancy reduced deficiency risk.
population_specificity: Primiparous women with low-risk, singleton pregnancies in Ireland (98.2% Caucasian, 80.6% born in Ireland).
study_duration: Measurements at 15, 20, and 33 weeks of gestation

study_goal: The researchers aimed to develop a nutritious, affordable complementary porridge fortified with iron and other nutrients to address deficiencies in African children.
results_summary: The study achieved satisfactory iron fortification in the porridge, meeting nutritional needs without compromising consistency or taste. The fortified porridge was cost-effective and met energy and nutrient requirements.
population_specificity: Children in Sub-Saharan Africa suffering from malnutrition.
effective_dosage: Not specified (iron salts were included as ingredients, but exact dosage not detailed).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to map interventions, including iron supplementation, to improve vitamin and mineral inadequacies among children in India.
results_summary: The study found that iron supplementation, along with other nutritional interventions, effectively reduced anemia in children. Various forms of iron delivery, including fortified foods and supplements, showed positive outcomes.
population_specificity: Children and adolescents aged 6 months to 19 years in India.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate gastrointestinal tolerability, treatment persistence, and iron status markers in patients with iron deficiency anaemia (IDA) receiving oral iron replacement therapy (IRT).
results_summary: The abstract does not provide specific results regarding the effects of iron, only the study's aims.
population_specificity: Patients with iron deficiency anaemia (IDA).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine the relationship between maternal anemia during pregnancy and neonatal hemoglobin levels.
results_summary: The meta-analysis found that maternal anemia during pregnancy was associated with significantly lower neonatal hemoglobin levels (1.38 g/dL lower in newborns of anemic mothers compared to non-anemic mothers). This suggests a correlation between maternal anemia and reduced neonatal hemoglobin levels.
population_specificity: Pregnant women and their newborns.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to assess the iron (Fe) content in food supplements available in Poland to evaluate compliance with declared values and market quality.
results_summary: The study found that 69.73% of the preparations contained more iron than declared, 11.00% contained less, and only 19.27% were within the norm, indicating significant variability in iron content. The findings suggest a need for improved manufacturing processes and stricter market controls.
population_specificity: Food supplements available in Poland, purchased from stationary and online pharmacies.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the effects of alpha-lipoic acid (ALA) supplementation on iron levels and other cardiovascular-related factors in patients with chronic kidney disease (CKD).
results_summary: The study found that ALA supplementation (600 mg/day) did not significantly affect iron levels or hemoglobin in CKD patients. No significant changes were observed in weight loss, body mass index, or iron following supplementation.
population_specificity: Patients with chronic kidney disease (CKD).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare the effectiveness of intravenous ferric carboxymaltose (FCM) versus oral iron supplementation in reducing blood transfusion requirements during delivery in third-trimester pregnant women with iron deficiency anaemia (IDA).
results_summary: IV FCM significantly increased hemoglobin levels at delivery (11.09 g/dL vs. 9.44 g/dL) and reduced postpartum transfusion rates (6% vs. 18.75%) compared to oral iron. The study concluded IV FCM was more effective than oral iron in managing IDA during pregnancy.
population_specificity: Third-trimester pregnant women with hemoglobin levels <10 g/dL and iron deficiency anaemia, excluding those with hematological/chronic systemic diseases or high-risk pregnancies.
study_duration: From third trimester until delivery (exact duration not specified)
